line_1: Varnish or hide the greatness of my loss,
line_2: "Then truly tell me, nor with flattering gloss,

line_1: I seldom have met with a loss,
line_2: My fountains all border'd with moss,

line_1: Then to contribute to my loss,
line_2: My knife and fork were laid across,
Scourg'd and nail'd him to the Cross.

line_1: All Things for Thee I count but Loss;
line_2: My only Glory be thy Cross!

line_1: Bewilder'd once, must he bewail his loss
line_2: For ever and for ever? No — the cross.

line_1: Pleased with the melancholy scene, each loss
line_2: I bless the peaceful mound, the mouldering cross,

line_1: To Providence I attribute my Loss.
line_2: Vain-glorious Man do's thus the Praise engross,

line_1: As God's expedient to retrieve his loss,
line_2: Point to the cure, describe a Saviour's cross

line_1: His Presence only must retrieve That Loss:
line_2: Marlbrô to Her must be what William was.

line_1: I own, said Will, I'm at a loss,
line_2: You press the point so very close;

line_1: All speakers, yet all language at a loss.
line_2: The flirted fan, the bridle and the toss,

line_1: To prove that without Christ, all gain is loss,
line_2: All hope, despair, that stands not on his cross,

line_1: Finds all his Gains repaid with Loss,
line_2: The guilty Soul with keen Remorse
